qas.question: How many grammatical cases can nouns and adjectives be declined into in Czech?
When are nouns in Czech inflected?

answers.text: to indicate their use in a sentence

qas.question: How does Czech mark subject nouns?
What nouns does Czech use the accusative case to mark?
What must an adjective's case agree with in Czech?
What age do children usually begin understanding grammatical cases?
What happens to case numbers to indicate them in a sentence?
What type of instrumental music do Czech children learn in school?
What are three types of instrumental cases?
What does a secondary object agree with?

context: In Czech, nouns and adjectives are declined into one of <a0_0><b5_0>seven<b5_0/><a0_0/> grammatical cases. Nouns are <b6_0>inflected<b6_0/> <a1_0>to indicate their use in a sentence<a1_0/>. A nominative–accusative language, Czech marks subject nouns <a2_0>with nominative case<a2_0/> and <a3_0>object<a3_0/> nouns with accusative case. The genitive case marks possessive nouns and some types of movement. The remaining cases (instrumental, <b8_0>locative, vocative and dative<b8_0/>) indicate semantic relationships, such as secondary objects, movement or position (dative case) and <b7_0>accompaniment<b7_0/> (instrumental case). An adjective's case agrees with that of <a4_0><b9_0>the noun it describes<b9_0/><a4_0/>. When Czech children learn their language's declension patterns, the cases are referred to by number:
